<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of handle_req_headers_no_space:
```c
static void
handle_req_headers_no_space (struct MHD_Connection *c,
                             const char *add_header,
                             size_t add_header_size)
{
  unsigned int err_code;

  err_code = get_no_space_err_status_code (c,
                                           MHD_PROC_RECV_HEADERS,
                                           add_header,
                                           add_header_size);
  transmit_error_response_static (c,
                                  err_code,
                                  ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG);
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
transmit_error_response_static (c,                                  err_code,                                  ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The call itself does not invoke any <string.h> functions, so this fragment alone does not violate Rule 21.17. A violation could occur if transmit_error_response_static internally copies ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG into a fixed-size buffer using unsafe string functions. Example: transmit_error_response_static has a local buffer char buf[32]; and does strcpy(buf, ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG) or memcpy(buf, ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG, strlen(ERR_MSG_REQUEST_HEADER_TOO_BIG)+1), where the message length exceeds 31 characters — this would access beyond the destination bounds and violate Rule 21.17.
